When a system contains two or more components with different concentrations, there is a natural tendency for a mass to be transferred minimizing the concentration differences. Important
The transport of one constituent from a region of higher concentration to that of a lower concentration is called as mass transfer
The difference in concentration (or partial pressure) is the driving force.


Diffusive (or molecular) - Occurs in absence of any microscopic motion in the medium. There are two types - molecular and eddy diffusion
Convective (or forced) - Occurs in presence of motion in the medium

item.title: Chemical Process Control
item.description:
Control systems are called for 3 general classes of problems: suppressing the influence of external disturbances, ensuring the stability of chemical processes, and optimizing the performance of a chemical process



I would explain what each variable means but I assume our reader has half a brain to comprehend
The above diagram is how variables in a chemical process control system are classified


Define the control objectives - "what are the operational objectives a control system is called upon to achieve?" -> the answer lies in the three type of problems the control system is called to solve
Select measurements - "what variables should we measure in order to monitor the operational performance of a plant?" -> so these are the measurements you need to be able to make regarding the control objectives of your system. The output variables. The ones that are classified as "measured" are "primary measurements" and "unmeasured" are "secondary measurements"
Select the manipulated variables - "What are the manipulated variables that can be used to control a process?" -> input variables you can change to make a control loop
Select the control configuration
Design the controller - no question here, no selection here, just straight up get programming and soldering


A control configuration is the information structure that is used to connect the available measurements to the available manipulated variables
Depending on number of inputs and outputs, we can distinguish control configurations as single input single output (SISO) or multiple input multiple output (MIMO)
Three general types of control configurations exist:
Feedback control configuration: uses direct measurements of controlled variables to adjust manipulated variables
Inferential control configuration: uses secondary measurements(the controlled variables can't be measured) to adjust the values of manipulated variables. An estimator uses the inputs and outputs to make an estimation of where the controlled variable is at. Sort of like how an inertial navigation machine in airplanes works
Feedforward control configuration: direct measurement of the disturbances to adjust values of manipulated variables


In process control, the hardware used is: process equipment, sensors, transducers (convert signals between analog and digital), transmission lines Intro to CPC, controller, final control element, recording elements
the final control element is the hardware that can manipulate a variable
Problems on intro to CPC

item.title: Chemical Reaction Engineering Problems
item.description:
Question A-> B is carried out in a CSTR, , calculate the volume necessary to get 80% conversion in CSTR, or spacetime for 80% conversion
Solution
Data Problem A reaction A->R gives the data on starting reaction from C_a0 = 1gmol/litre

the left column is the conc in gmol/m3 and right is time(actually the other way round sorry)
how much will the conversion at 300min be if the reaction starts at half c_a0? ->
Solution 60%
Levenspiel 3.24
Done
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt CA = [1,2,4,6,7,9,12] ra = [0.06,0.1,0.25,1.0,2.0,1.0,0.5] def interpolate_kewl(op): for v,i in enumerate(CA): if i>=op: p1 = [CA[v-1],ra[v-1]] p2 = [CA[v],ra[v]] break slope = (p2[1]-p1[1])/(p2[0]-p1[0]) return slope*(op-p1[0])+p1[1] arr_eval = np.linspace(1,12,100) time_spend = 0 time = [] for i in arr_eval: time_spend+=(11/100)/interpolate_kewl(i) time.append(time_spend) plt.plot(arr_eval,time) plt.show()

item.title: CPC Math
item.description:
Under Construction
Need to flesh out the objective and the contents of this page better, along with a few solved problems
Two approaches - empirical and theoretical. Won't go into what each means because it's obvious

In order to characterize a processing system, we need:
A set of fundamental dependent quantities whose values will describe the natural state of the system
A set of equations in the fundamental quantities which will describe how the natural state of the given system changes with time The book then states the conservation laws as the equations - conservation of mass and energy
The equations along with the fundamental quantities form a differential equation with time as the independent variable and the fundamental quantities as the dependent variables
The solution of the differential equation defines the dynamic behaviour of the system


The time between the inputs being changes and the effect viewed in the system is called the dead time or lag time
Real life is never ideal and theres almost always dead time


Pretty simple - a systems outputs expressed as a function of it's inputs



number of independently variables that can define the process completely
more on this on a later date

item.title: Filtration
item.description:
A removal of solids from a fluid by passing through a filter medium (septum) on which the solids are deposited

Carried out to recover solid/fluid or none of them or both
Covers range of solid content from traces to a high percentage
Driving force is the pressure difference
Types of filters
Mechanism of filtration
Constant pressure filtration
Constant rate filtration
Filter aid
Filter media - must retain solids to be filtered, must not plug/blind, must be resistant chemically and mechanically to survive the process conditions, must be affordable and allow cake to be cleaned off
Cake deliquoring, dewatering - carried out to further reduce the moisture content of the filter cake. Done by pushing or pulling the air (vacuum) or mechanical squeezing
Cake dewatering improves the cake discharge and handling, reducing the transportation costs and removes the contaminated liquids from the cake

Major process variables - temperature, flow, pressure, level, composition

The first letter of a signal is what its detecting and the second is for what it's being used for
If the second letter is "I", then it's an indicator, for display. If the second letter is "T", its transmittance, for control system feedback
signal transmission is done through electrical or pneumatic
Pneumatic signals are for short distances, electrical through normal distance and for very long signals, digital

"A signal is a flow of information"



A voltage is created between T1 and T2 because of their temperatures and is in the microvolt level
This is because of the seabeck effect - two junctions, at different temperatures cause a voltage
Peltier effect is when you put a voltage, one junction becomes hot and the other becomes cold
The voltage does not vary linearly with temperature and thus a calibration polynomial must be used
Thompson effect - voltage generated due to temperature gradient between two points
The smallest change in temperature for which a change in voltage takes place is the resolution of the sensor. Important
Resolution is the smallest change in the variable for which a change can be detected
Sensitivity is how big of a change in signal is caused due to a unit change in a variable
Note the difference
Accuracy - how close the measurement is to the true value. Error = Actual Value - Measured Value
The time a sensor takes to give the measurement is called the dynamic lag. Like when you put a thermometer in your mouth, it takes some time to give the temperature. The time this takes is called the dynamic lag. How fast my system responds to the change
Precision is the reproducibility of your measurement
Todo Assignment - Resistance Thermometer

Pressure sensor - strain gauge > simplest type of pressure sensor
A differential pressure sensor has two pressures at two different sides with a diaphragm in the middle which deforms an element with properties that vary with deformation in the conductivity

the larger particles get clogged and the smaller particles are unable to get through
This is the cake thats formed


Feed slurry to a filter with a pressure difference due to gravity
Initially there is no filter cake, over time the filter cake is developed
The slurry passes through the filter and is removed as the filtrate
Filtration is a special case of flow through porous media
There are two resistances in filtration which the filtrate media and the cake resistance in the pressure drop. The cake resistance becomes the controlling resistance
We modify the flow through porous media equations for filtration for this reason
With time either the flow rate decreases or the pressure drop increases

1820 -> This guy, Thomas Hancock, found a way to blend additives to rubber (a natural polymer) by beating it up (masticating it)
1839 -> Charles Goodyear added sulphur to rubber and found it got stronger. This process was named vulcanization.
1846 - 1870 -> Some guy prepared nitrocellulose, sold it as an explosive. Another guy thought to mold it and make items out of it as it was found it be a hard elastic material that is also soluble and easily mold-able. Two other guys thought it would be smart to do this with something that isn't an explosive - celluloid. Instant commercial success.
1892 -> Cross, Bevan and Beadle patented the viscose process for dissolving and regenerating cellulose
1920s -> This absolute chad of a human, Hermann Staudinger studied the synthesis, structure and properties of polyoxymethylene and polystyrene to give emprical evidence of his idea that polymers are really just macromolecules containing large sequences of monomers. Everyone doubted him, but the haters were proven wrong

The general form of the transfer function of a second order system is:
When C>1, its overdamped, C=1 critically damped and C<1 underdamped go through the cases in the book and report the formulae here

overdamped systems literally damp out all the sin and cos stuff, underdamped, you still see some oscillation and critically damped systems are in between the two

Larger values of C exhibit a slow sluggish response
When C goes lower, the oscillatory behaviour increases

overshoot is how much the response exceeds the ultimate value following a step change
decay ratio is defined as the square of the sizes of the successive peaks

Substituting i\omega: The magnitude of this term is the AR (amplitude ratio)
This is done to get the frequency response of the system on a sinusoidal (?) input
Substitute this in second order and you get the amplitude ratio

You have the linear skeletal polymers which are just chains with two ends - Linear Polymers

Based on the identities of the monomers making up the polymer, we classify them as homopolymers and copolymers

The classification most people use when speaking about polymers is of them divided into - thermoplastics, elastomers and thermosets
Thermoplastics are linear of branched polymers which become liquid upon application of heat. They can be moulded and remoulded into any shape. They do not crystallise easily. Many of these are amorphous - not crystalline - and are characterized by their glass transition temperature, at which they move between glassy and rubbery states. Can be remoulded multiple times
Elastomers are crosslinked polymers that are rubbery. They aren't called rubber since that word is for rubbery polymers that arent crosslinked. Elastomers are characterised by their capability to be stretched into large lengths and return to their original state. These are thermoplastics
Thermoset polymers are polymers that cant be remoulded or melted. They have very high degrees of crosslinking. Eg rubber after vulcanisation

item.title: entropy-arjun
item.description:
#thermo
#thermo
Related to Entropy
The requirement for this arises from linear algebra, of all things...

We have the mass balance, energy balance equations. These two are used to solve for two variables, which determine all the other variables in a state. Sometimes, these two equations aren't enough to determine the equilibrium conditions, here, a third equation, entropy balance is used - this is for a single phase, isolated system, multiphase is covered later
Also, the first two equations don't say much about what "can or cant" happen - they do, but there's still another constraint we need. A rock could instantly lower it's temperature and jump up by itself, and that would be alright if we just looked at energy and mass balances. This is why we need entropy balance.
In essence, we have nothing to describe equilibrium, and it's state in a system. Mass and energy balance are OK with any state as long as those two aren't violated.
Entropy is a state function. In a system in which there are flows of heat by conduction and flow of work across system boundaries, the conductive heat flow and not the work flow, causes a change in entropy of a system; This rate of change in entropy is Q/T where Q is the rate of heat conducted and T is the temperature. If in addition, there are mass flows at the boundaries, the total entropy will also change due to this convected flow. That is, each element of mass entering or leaving the system carries with it it's entropy
The equation, S, on the left hand side is the total entropy, while S on the right hand side (not S_gen), is the entropy per unit mass(couldnt figure out how to use carets in latex). S_gen is the entropy generated in the system due to inefficiencies, and must always be equal to or above 0

S_gen is the entropy created in a system, since this always must be above or equal to 0, the presence of it causes irreversibility. Irreversibility in the sense that the system is now forever different to what it was a moment ago, we can never turn back the clock and reduce entropy because S_gen can never be below 0. So unless it is equal to 0 all the time, the system will never go back to what it used to be.
Important Something funny that NO ONE says in class - all irreversibility can be traced back to conduction - viscous conduction. Even movement due to a finite pressure difference is irreversible purely because of viscous conduction due to friction. :/ This makes entropy so much easier to understand - its ALL heat conduction


Interesting consequence - reversible processes extracting work from the system to give to the surroundings, maximum work is done for a given change of state of the system (because so little energy is lost to conduction), the processes giving work to the system for a change of state require the least amount of work for it
Gibbs Energy Arjun


This is a cycle - you got the condenser, the evaporator, the nozzle and the compressor. The compressor puts work in the system, makes the fluid high pressure, liquid. The nozzle causes isentropic (not really) expansion, condenser releases heat to the surroundings, evaporator absorbs heat from the cooled substance.
The trick to refrigeration which I wasn't able to get in Entropy, is that the heat put in from the cold side and the heat released into the hot side isnt the same, the heat in the hot side is the cold side+ work shaft

item.title: Processing
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers

You process a polymer at it's processing temperature. In case of polymers the processing temperature is above it's melting temperature
To reduce the resistance of the material, you need to increase the temperature above the melt temperature to reduce viscosity. Generally about 10C higher than melting point
Polymer processing is done for application, study of properties and to reduce the cost of a compound by adding a filler or use a cheaper material along with the polymer
First part of processing is called dry blending then melt blending. Not strictly a requirement


Dry blending - You don't allow the polymer to melt when processing. Example - you have one powder phase and one pellet/granular phase and they're just mixed up. Can't be regularly agitated since the powder will separate from the granules due to difference in density. Oily phase to be added to the mixture so the powder is tied to the granules. The oily phase is called a wetting agent and that causes adsorption/ soaking of the powder on the granule.
The granules are added then wetting agent then powder at the end. The wetting agent isn't added in the end because this would cause the powder to be clumped up together
When you're mixing in a tumbler, the rpm you choose is important. The optimized speed is a problem. The RPM where you're getting a constant bulk density is the optimum speed

To know when something is properly mixed you sample and check the bulk density. The bulk density is measured using a British cylinder
Melt blending - Melt 'n Mix after making a uniform dry blend as written above. It's not mandatory all the time to have dry then melt processing, you can go directly to melt by using feeders.


Extrusion is a continuous output with positive displacement.
A cycle air pump is not an extruder since it retracts and this it is not continuous
A screw is used to extrude polymer to have a continuous positive displacement

To increase the mixing, you must reduce the distance between the screw and the barrel. This has the consequence of reducing the mass flow
Should the shear profile be constant or profile(non constant) through the extrusion? It shouldn't because it wouldnt be mixed properly if it was
You mostly use thermoplastic in an extruder
Screw has 3 zones - feed zone, compression/transition zone and the metering zone(?)
Screw will be tapered (thicker toward the end)
feed zone you're feeding the material from the hopper. It's only there to convey the material
Compression zone is for intensive shear mixing of the polymer to be extruded
metering zone is to push the mixed polymer through a die (the stuff that extrudes it)
L/D ratio of the screw is the ratio of the screw groove diameter to the length of the screw
the clearance of the screw is different at different zones. Feed zone the clearance is high. end of the compression zone the clearance is low and the metering zone it's constant at low. Clearance is the distance between the end of the grove of the screw and the wall of the extruder Todo understand how the clearance changes between different parts and why. Actually just study all of extrusion from somewhere
compression ratio:

RPM of the screw cant vary
Temperature will not be constant throughout, the temperature at the feed zone is less and the temperature as you go ahead increases to slowly melt and mix and extrude it
If the temperature at the feed zone is high, the extruder will get clogged as the stuff will stick to the screw when it melts Extrusion is a positive displacement technique. Considered to be an adiabatic technique and every zone is isothermal (the temperature doesn't variably change, it is fixed at the melt temperature at non feed zones). Metering zone has screen plate (mesh) and breaker plate(supports the screen plate) right before the die. The screen plate is to restrict unmelted polymer. Breaker plate converts turbulent to laminar flow.
There are three types of flows in an extruder - the drag flow (dragged by the screw), pressure flow (pressure from the screen and breaker plate, causing backflow, better mixing) and leakage flow (clearance leakage) Danger compression ratio has nothing to do with actual pressure - it's just a metric for mixing


Single motor, two screws, parallel, no tapered design. Screws both move clockwise, there will be pressure buildup since the screws are different directionally threaded (co-rotating). Co rotating has a bad shear profile but good mixing
It also be non - corotating - counter rotating. The screws both move in different directions and the mixture flows in an infinite symbol shape. counter rotating has a better shear profile but bad mixing and bad distribution of filler in extruded material
Danger Shear profile and rate are NOT THE SAME. Counter rotating has a better shear profile but not shear rate apparently


It can be non intermeshing(?) also
It provides better mixing compared to single screw extruder
Segmented screw has different types of screws in the shaft so you can add different types of screws at different zones as required Important Distributing mixing: distributes small particles
Dispersive mixing: dispereses big particles

item.title: Properties of Polymers
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers

Polymers are always covalently bonded
With high inductive effect, low molar mass molecules are liberated as the electronegative group abstracts hydrogen from the carbon
Primary bonding - covalent and ionic
Secondary - Configuration and conformation
Configuration - you cant change this without breaking the bonds
Conformation - this is related to the rotation of the bonds
Tacticity - relating to the stereochemistry of repeating units
Tacticity - isotacticity, atacticity and syndiostereotacticity

The above is isotactic
Glass transition temperature - when you heat the polymer, there is a transition phase, called glass transition. Mostly polymers are semicrystalline or amorphous - glass transition is when the polymer is in amorphous state. The lower this temperature, the more flexible the polymer is. Used in thermoplastic. Above , polymer is flexible and below it it is glassy. is the temperature below which the polymer is mostly rigid
Tg causes a second order phase change

The is the temperature when the specific volume vs temperature graph has a change in slope
DSC - differential scanning calorimetry, can find the , , , gel point, everything
DMTA - dynamic mechanical and thermal analysis
DSC and DMTA are two techniques to get the value
Melting temperature - Used in thermoplastic.
Melting temperature - related to heat gain
Crystallization temperature, - Used in thermoplastic. When you cool the polymer it starts crystallizing. When the entropy change is the highest - peak crystallization temperature
Semi crystalline polymer shows , and . Amorphous only shows
Semi Crystalline polymers is defined by how regular the packing of the polymer is.

item.title: Bias-Variance
item.description:
the mean squared error in models shows the accuracy
It can be shown that it decomposes to:

the bias of the function squared, variance of the function and variance of the irreducible error term
variance of the function is how much the prediction of some x0 would change if we estimated it on different datasets, same with the error term's variance
In general, more flexible methods have more more variance. You would see deep learning have a higher variance than linear regression
bias is the error that is because we're estimating a real life problem. Its the difference between what we got vs whats actually there
Usually, with more flexible methods, bias initially decreases,hits a hard bottom, then variance starts to increase
So basically if bias is high, you dont have a model that understands your data at all
If your variance is high, you've overfit and cant use your model to extrapolate
Mostly, when the bias decreases, variance increases and vice versa
The trick is to get both at a low amount

Viscous force at particle surface

item.description:
A fluid cannot be fluidized
Fluidised beds were known only to academicians for many years, until adoption of fluidized catalysts by the petroleum industry
Fluidized beds behave as a single fluid of density equal to that of mixture of solids
It is assumed in fluidized beds that one phase is a solid The danger of saying today Some drunk johnny boy was taking round and met his commanding officer. His commanding officer was sober. Johnny boy wrote in his diary, "today, my commanding officer was not drunk". Think on the danger of this statement


Fluidised catalytic bed reactors
fluidisation - make solids behave as if they were liquid. The upward thrust should be exactly and equal to the downward force

The above graph is the effect of fluid velocity on pressure gradient and delta P
So basically this shows how the friction factor changes with velocity
When fluidisation just starts, its called minimum or incipient fluidisation
The del P per unit length decreases on start of fluidisation since the length increases since the particles move upwards
In fluidization you do not want to carry away the solids.
When a fluid flows slowly upwards through a bed of very fine particles, the flow is streamline and a linear relation exists between the pressure gradient and flow rate
If log(delP/Ltube) is plotted against log(Vavg), a straight line of slope 1 is obtained
In a fluidised bed, total frictional force on particles = effective weight of bed
Thus in a bed of cross sectional area A, depth Ltube, and porosity epsilon, additional pressure drop across bed due to layout weight of particles is given by:

The area cancels out
This relationship applies between the initial expansion of the bed till the transport of the bed

Channeling results in drag force reducing
Agglomeration - particles come together

There are two types of models that estimate f,parametric and non parametric
parametric approaches basically get the problem of f down to a certain number of parameters that must be found. The model is decided from before hand and the parameters are optimized for the error

parametric methods need less data compared to nonparametric methods for the same task
eg. linear regressions cant be used to predict the shape of a projectile

item.title: Pumps
item.description:
wp is work of pump per unit volume
theres also alpha at the velocity heads that is multiplied. I don't know what it stands for

What is suction head? When there is no movement, there is P_1 and P_2 at the two points because of possibly height difference
P_1 and H_1 exist regardless of flow, but if the pump is not on, the v_1 is 0 We are talking about inherently failproof design.
There is no suction in centrifugal pumps, but in reciprocating pumps, there is a suction power. This is why the centrifugal pump needs a little head value to get going. Tldr Centrifugal pump just sucks at sucking and thus needs a little energy to get the fluid to keep the suction side flooded. This is not a problem with reciprocating pumps because they're better at sucking (in all areas, theyre just bad pumps and they make so much noise)
We must subtract vapour pressure from the suction head to get the net positive suction head. This is because the vapour potential head is negligible so we do a vapour correction. This net positive suction head must be more than 0. The vapour be eating into our head cus del h has gas density negligible so it becomes P+rho g (h-hgas) hgas comes from bubble formation
We subtract to remove any remote possibility of the suction head suffering from the vapour pressure. MINUS DA FRICTIONAL LOSSES ALSO BROO The suction head cannot suffer!!
net positive suction head for bigger pumps is 7-10 meters and for smaller pumps it's 3-4 meters.

Line source - Emits radiation only at select wavelengths

Chemical energy is provided by exothermic or chemiluminescent reactions
In a continuum source, nominal wavelength is the wavelength which the wavelength selector is set to pass (its not exactly that, since its continuum)
Effective bandwidth - the width of the band of radiation passing through a wavelength selector measured at half the bands height
Resolution - separation between two spectral features, narrow effective bandwidth increases resolution
FIlters narrow the bandwidth

item.title: PS Overview
item.description:
#safety
#safety
This subject is actually pretty cool

Safety - its the use of technologies to prevent disasters before they occur
Hazard - a chemical or physical condition that has the potential to cause damage
Risk - A measure of human injury, environmental damage or economic loss in terms of both incident likelihood and magnitude of loss or injury
Engineering ethics - with the given resources, engineers must make a safe and secure working environment. This is a responsibility to society


Important statistics in weighing the merits and demerits of different safety systems:
OSHA incidence rate - number of worker injuries per 100 worker years. One worker year is assumed to contain 2000 worker hours.
OSHA incidence rate can also be on the basis of lost workdays
Fatality rate (per year)
Fatal Accident Rate - Used by the british chemical industry, number of fatalities per 1000 employees working a full lifetime, so FAR is 10^8 worker hours

Accident stats can be misleading as major causes of death like the bhopal incident are in one single event
Acceptable levels of risk, for any procedure - if the plant has more than one procedure (always...), the levels of risk must be much much less than the levels for normally sitting at home, since the risks of exposure form multiple processes can be additive

Chemical Accidents follow typical patterns

Mostly comprise of fires, explosions and vapour cloud explosions. Also a little bit of windstorms and flooding

Explosions cause a lot of economic loss. Vapour cloud explosions occur when a large cloud of volatile and flammable vapour is released unconfined in the whole plant, then ignited
Toxic release causes little capital loss, however, lots of lawsuits and deaths
Almost all accidents not caused by natural disaster can be attributed to human error or mechanical error. Other causes can be process upsets, design or sabotage
piping systems, storage tanks followed by reactor piping systems are the biggest locations of accidents
Accidents follow a three step process: initiation, propagation and termination



An inherently safe plant relies on process chemistry and physics rather than control systems, interlocks, redundancy and all to stop accidents
layers of safety above the process are of no interest to inherent design (they are needed, but inherent design focuses mostly on the first layer, which is the process itself)
Inherent design is described using four words - minimize(intensification), substitute, moderate(attenuation and limitation of effects) and simplify(simplification and error tolerances)
minimize - reduce storage and usage of hazardous chemicals in process, if possible, they should be produced and consumed in situ
substitute - use different materials in the process
moderate - use the hazardous materials in less hazardous conditions, such as refrigerated, in low vapour pressure, using larger particle sizes to reduce dust issues (flash explosions)
simplify - make the plant simpler by : designing controls to be placed in a friendly, logical manner, separating processes to prevent domino effect, etc

Just read the above, no need to memorize



Nypro limited produced 70,000 tonnes a year of caprolactam, used in production of nylon
Process used cyclohexane, which volatilizes immediately in atmospheric conditions
six reactors in series oxidising cyclohexane to cyclohexanol using inhected air in the presence of a catalyst. Each reactor containing 20 tonnes of cyclohexane
reactor 5 had a leak - a vertical crack in it's stainless steel structure. They removed the reactor for repairs. They then connected reactor 4 to reactor 6
Actual pipes were 28 inches in diameter, they only had 20 inches. They made a workaround and created a bypass.
Bypass didnt have enough support, overflexed, and ruptured
30 tons of cyclohexane were freed, forming a vapour cloud, which was then ignited, levelling the entire facility and killed a number of people


Bhopal Accident


Explosion occurred at the wastewater tank at the ARCO chemical plant in channelview, texas
Oxygen analyser didnt detect flammable atmosphere in the tank, (due to buildup of peroxides), the flammable vapours got sucked into the compressor when it restarted and ignited
this happened during maintenance
proper MOC procedures should have been followed before maintenance work


Ammonium nitrate explosion, port neal iowa
Process shut down, AN was left in vessels
The nitric acid plant was shut down, to prevent backflow of AN into the nitric acid line, 200 psig steam was applied through a nitric acid sparger.
AN is more sensitive to decomposition at higher temperatures, other plants were stricter about steam sparges
Process safety knowledge is the RBPS element causing this
There should have been a HAZOP study, so another element could be "Process Knowledge Management" and "HAZOP"

Anionic surfactants (?) are used at 1-5 wt% of the monomer. they have hydrophobic hydrocarbon molecules on one end and a hydrophillic anionic head group. These surfactant molecules, when dissolved in water, above their "critical micelle concentration", begin associating into groups of spherical aggregates called micelles, which contain about 100 molecules.
These micelles contain a hydrophobic core, which can absorb a good amount of water insoluble substances
When monomer is added, 3 phases develop - aqueous phase with small amounts of monomer and surfactant, large droplets containing lots of monomer and surfactant, small droplets (very very common) containing some monomer and surfactant around


This is the stage where particles are formed. What are particles? The book doesn't say - I guess they are drops but polymer. Particle nucleation occurs through three methods:

Micellular Nucleation - Micelle receives oligomeric radical formed from initiator and monomer in aqueous phase. Micelle keeps growing and attracting more monomer until no more micelles left without radical.
Homogeneous nucleation - chain radical formed, attracted surfactant for colloidal stability and monomers for propagation. Ends when these particles get big enough to attract even oligomeric radicals
Coagulation nucleation - A bunch of oligomeric radicals clump up together until the molecule is big enough to achieve colloidal stability itself and then starts absorbing monomer and propagates
Micellular nucleation happens when the solution is well above CMC, homogeneous is when surfactant is little and coagulation is when surfactant is even less

in the first part of particle growth (AKA interval 2), monomers are provided by monomer droplets to the particles, to keep them propagating. When all the monomer droplets are used up, we enter interval 3, when rate of polymerization continuously decreases


Taking Smith Ewart's Case 2, each particle can be assumed to have only one radical at a time and when another enters, the two react extremely fast to terminate. This way, each particle has, on average one radical, half the time:


Formation of core shell structures, Good for the environment, widely used in industry
Contamination by inorganic salts and dispersion stabilizers is the biggest problem

#polymers
The trickiest thing about polymerization isn't initiation or propagation but termination

wood is a composite of cellulose and lignin - polyphenolic compound. Lignin binds the cellulose


Emulsion polymerization - used where two phases are immiscible, polymer formed is in a single phase. The substance used to bind the phases is called an emulsifier. Emulsifiers are used to match the surface energy of the two phases. Acrylic emulsions are in pharma, paints and cosmetics.
Solution polymerization -
Suspension polymerization
Bulk polymerization


The most basic requirement of polymerization is that each monomer must have a functionality greater than 2
Functionality is the number of bonds it can make with other functional groups of other monomers
Carothers classified polymerization reactions into addition polymerization and condensation polymerization. This classification isn't in use anymore as there was some overlap between the two
The method of classifying polymerization reactions is in step growth and chain growth polymerizations
Step growth polymerizations are characterized by a high rate of reaction at the start, levelling out later. For these polymerizations, high extent of reactions (of the functional groups) are required for high chain lengths
Chain growth polymerizations have a constant rate of reaction from start to end Important Polymers don't have a boiling point because of how large their molecular mass is and because they degrade before they can boil


The various types of copolymers are:
Homopolymer: a-a-a-a-a
Random copolymer: a-b-b-a-a-b-a-b
Alternating copolymer: a-b-a-b-a-b
Block copolymer: a-a-a-a-a-b-b-b-b-b
Graft copolymer: a-a-a-a-a-a

Since we know, from experiment, that the equilibrium of a single component single phase system is controlled by only two state variables, we can express any other variable as the function of these two variables in the following manner:

This is like taking a substance from one state to the other by keeping one variable constant, then changing the other, then doing the other way round

This can be better understood from linear algebra, when there are two independent variables and a bunch of dependent variables. A thermodynamic system is the same. We can look at it like a vector space

For open systems, a sizing parameter like number of moles can also be added to the mix

An interesting nature of the partial derivatives shown above is that they depend on the path you take. dU/dT at constant volume is not the same as taking it at constant pressure. This is because moving it along the constant pressure line will give a different value as well, making the total the same. Also the final state itself is different if you just change the temperature at constant pressure vs constant volume, so you're really comparing apples to oranges
Important A few important things:

This is the triple product rule, If X increases with Y (holding Z constant), and Z increases with X (holding Y constant), then Y must decrease with Z (holding X constant) to keep the overall relationship consistent

item.title: Temperature
item.description:
#thermo
#thermo

This seems like an odd topic to make a note on, but it's really important to understand
Temperature is that quantity that is the same in two substances (regardless of what they are) when they are in thermal equilibrium. Thermal equilibrium is when there is not heat flow between them.
This definition of temperature leads to all sorts of temperature scales but two things really narrow down the choices:
One - the scale should cause temperature to increase with the degree of "hotness"
Two - the ratio of energy flow out to entropy change is equal to temperature. This concept will be better understood after reading entropy
From here we can define heat - the energy flow from a system due to temperature difference is heat. This, I expect, will anger any sane reader - how can temperature and heat have such self referencing definitions (is that the right term?). To that I'll join you. The scientists have really done some weird stuff
Work is the other component of energy flow, which is characterised by mechanical motion between system boundaries
heat and work are really fundamentally different in the sense, that all of work can be converted into heat energy, but the reverse is not possible
The above gets infinitely more confusing when we get to entropy, so enjoy
That's all I'll write on temperature as of now

item.title: Bulk Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
Simple - uses monomer and monomer soluble initiator. The monomer is where the reactions occur for polymerization, not in any other medium
This is good for high purity, high molar mass products, good for polycondensation. Polyaddition is better suited for Solution Polymerization, its also good for polycondensation
Issues with bulk polymerization are with heat transfer (if heat is generated, it's difficult to remove and causes autoacceleration) and viscosity buildup. These are solved by only allowing low conversion.
Polystyrene is an example of a polymer made using bulk polymerization
Advantages

High yield per reactor volume
Easy Polymer Recovery
The option of casting the polymerization mixture into final product form
Limitations:
Difficulty in removing last traces of monomer
The problem of dissipating heat produced during the reaction. This can be improved by providing special baffles
The problem of viscosity buildup in the reactor

item.title: Radical Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
-All these notes are derived from intro to polymerization, I don't hide this fact, it's the truth-

If step growth was about simple reactions occurring between monomers and polymers to grow the chain, radical polymerization is about the propagation of a free radical end which keeps growing it.
It's used for unsaturated monomers

Radical polymerization undergoes several chemical reactions that determine the end polymers' structures. These reactions include:

Radical Polymerization Initiation - Specific chemicals that generate free radicals, which react with monomers that cause free radical polymer chains
Radical Polymerization Propagation - How the free radical polymer chains keep growing
Radical Polymerization Termination - How the free radical polymer chains lose their free radicals and become "dead chains"
Radical Polymerization Chain Transfer - Where the free radical area gets transferred to a different chain

A lot of this has been covered in the previous section, I'm just developing it here - getting it all together


Using kinetics analysis, without taking into account chain transfer:

Using kinetics analysis, taking into account chain transfer to get the Mayo Walling Equation


At different conversions, the diffusive properties of the chains differ (lol). This is important because these diffusive properties, control how molecules meet each other and react. Thus if they are low enough in any area they can cause certain parts of the radical polymerization mechanism to go slower or faster. Certain parts can be "diffusion controlled"
Types of diffusion

Segmental Diffusion - Refers to orientation of molecules reacting. Propagation and termination are controlled by this at low conversions since they molecules have to be in correct orientation to react and translational diffusion when the chain is small is good
Translational Diffusion - Refers to actual diffusion (the centre of mass moves). Controls the termination step at high conversions. An interesting effect, known as autoacceleration or the Trommsdorf-Norrish effect occurs when reaction mixtures become translational diffusion controlled - the termination step decreases and since propagation is not affected by translational diffusion (monomers still diffuse about easily), the conversion increases and the termination step decreases more, so on and so on. The reaction mixture becomes really viscous and even glass like (vitrifies)
Reactive diffusion - everything slow, chains move only by adding new monomers

Molar Mass Distribution - when I finally make this page, I'm including this there

Situation is different for combination and Mn/Mw ends up being (2+B)/2

Ceiling temperature - the temperature at with propagation stops due to the reaction becoming non spontaneous. There's an equation for this, I'll add it later, when they teach us this stuff probably

Solution Polymerization - homogeneous polymerization process
Suspension Polymerization - Heterogeneous Polymerization Process
Emulsion Polymerization - Heterogeneous Polymerization Process

item.title: Solution Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
Monomer and initiator are placed in a solvent, where they react
Solves the heat transfer and viscosity issue with Bulk Polymerization but causes new issues like chain transfer to solvent.
To isolate the polymer from the solvent, we either evaporate it off and if the polymer is insoluble in the solvent, we precipitate it off. Both these processes are inefficient and aren't used widely in industry
Prof's PPT

Heat removed during polymerization can be facilitated by conducting the polymerization in an organic solvent or water
Both the initiator and the monomer must be soluble in it
the solvent must have acceptable chain transfer characteristics and suitable melting and boiling points for the conditions of the polymerization and subsequent solvent removal step
Solvent choice may be influences by other factors such as flash point, cost and toxicity
Reactors are usually stainless steel or glass lined

item.title: Suspension Polymerization
item.description:
#polymers
#polymers
Better than solution polymerization. This requires the monomer and initiator to be insoluble in the solvent. The monomer and initiator are added, a suspension(whats the difference between a suspension and an emulsion?) is created, this is agitated at high speeds to create small droplets in which the polymerization reactions are taken into completion. After its complete, the polymer is filtered or centrifuged out. Dispersion stabilizers are also used (what are dispersion stabilizers? How do they work?)
This is great because the heat transfer surface is amazing, viscosity doesn't matter too much, widely used in industry.
According to sir, the only process that gives beads (not powder, much more than 10 micrometer), is suspension. So in exam write this
particles of size 10-1000 micrometer

item.title: Accounting
item.description:
The sales or revenue is also called the top line of a company
Important Accounting merely means recounting; and this process involves recording, classifying and summarizing of past events and transactions of financial nature with a view to enabling the user of accounts to interpret the resulting summary
Quote This planet hasor rather hada problem, which was this: most of the people living on it were unhappy for pretty much of the time. Many solutions were suggested for this problem, but most of these were largely concerned with the movement of small green pieces of paper, which was odd because on the whole it wasn't the small green pieces of paper that were unhappy. Douglas Adams


Inflow - Income (money coming in that isn't repayable), Debt/Liabilities (money coming in that is repayable), Selling Asset
Outflow - Expense (Something you're spending money on that you are getting the rewards of instantly, you don't get the money back), Assets (Something you're spending money on that you will get rewards of in long term and you get the money back - recoverable, whatever a firm holds and uses for a long period), Clearing Liability
Classification of transactions happens in these 6 areas ^
Income - Not repayable inflow
Liability - Repayable inflow
Expense - Not recoverable outflow
Assets - Recoverable in the future
Profit and loss is , P&L account deals with revenue
Balance sheet is in liabilities and assets, BL sheet deals with capital
To account for asset usage, depreciation cost is kept in expenses
Depreciation is a non cash expense


Tangible - Land, plant, machinery, etc.
Intangible - Goodwill, etc.
Whatever is payable is a liability, whatever is receivable is an asset
Whatever you use for a long period of time is also an asset


You buy a machine and depreciate it to 0 over 5 years in the machinery account, when you sell it, you log it as: income
If the machine breaks down before depreciation makes it 0, you file the rest as expense


Is an earning as a result of normal business activity or otherwise. It is also called sales turnover
Whatever is from the main core of the business is operating income


An expense is an outflow of money in return for a product or service. It is also known as cost


An asset is a resource which has economic usefulness in business operations over several years


A liability is an obligation owed by the business to any external stakeholder
Every transaction has atleast 2 effects in 1 or more of these 4 buckets
HW - ask about the number of accounts
HW - How many accounts would I have?


business owner and business are separate entities

the profits minus dividends are shown as a liability to the owner


each company is an ongoing operation - accounting is to be done with the idea that the company will never close down


Every transaction needs monetary term - no bartering


In the books of accounting, everything is accounted for at historical costs only
No notional or market values


whatever you're earning has to be matched - P&L is accurately depicted - transactions must be accounted for when its coming in


Accounting for things in the right period


you will account for a transaction even if actual cash isn't coming in
If it's coming in then account for it for sure
receivables are accounted for when they are accounted for not when they aren't
Treat every transaction in isolation
receivable account exists brother


anything that is significant enough for decision making should be disclosed separately
If any transaction is above a certain threshold, it has to be shown separately in the reports - the thresholds are set by the companies act
Some classifications have to be disclosed separately even if they aren't above the thresholds set by the companies act
any major event has to be disclosed


there are accounting standards - international, indian, etc.
bunch of rules that tell you how to account for different stuff
Although you are free to choose a standard, stick with it


You cannot record for a notional or forseeable profit but you must record for forseeable losses
Basically if you're happy, stop being happy because accounting doesn't want that
inventory is products unsold by the end of the year - matching principle says what didn't get sold cannot be taken as an expense. inventory is an asset
inventory is to be valued at market value or net realizable value, whichever is lower - exception to cost principle

When the benefits of the expenditure is not exhausted in the year in which it was incurred
An example of expenditures incurred is in purchase of fixed assets

Inventory
Short term loans These are called current assets


Proprietor - the person who invests his money in the business and bears all risks connected with the business is called the proprietor
Capital - It means amount invested by the proprietor in the business. For the business, capital is a liability towards the owner.
Drawings - It is the amount of money taken away by the proprietor for personal use


Debtor is someone who owns money to you - usually someone you've sold goods on credit
Other terms for debtor are - receivables, trade receivables, account receivables
Creditor is the person from whom the company has a debt from. Generally the vendor from whom they've bought stuff on credit
Payables, trade payables, accounts payables
Debtor is asset and creditor is liability


Goods - Purchased for resale or to produce finished products which are also meant to be sold
What the company trades or manufactures
Companies can be classified broadly into companies that sell goods and companies that sell services
In goods, companies can be classified into traders and manufacturers
There'll be a purchase account for all the inward movement of goods and a sales account for the outward movement of goods Hint The purchase account is expense, the other effect of purchase is cash (goes down)
The expense account is income and the other effect is cash (goes up) whatever you haven't sold at the end of the accounting period, is called the closing stock, whatever is in closing stock, in the next accounting period, becomes the opening stock "When you're buying, its expense, when you're selling it's sales, jo bachgaya hai, becomes inventory" Inventory isn't a transaction, but since you own it, it's an asset
Returns - Accounted as sales returns, when the customer doesn't like your stuff
Return inward
Return from you - accounted as purchase return, when you don't like your suppliers stuff
Return Outward
Goods which are in the transition stage if the processing time is high is called "work in progress"


Solvent - A person who is in a position to pay his debts as they become due
Insolvent - A person who is not in a position to pay his debts as they become due
When a customer doesn't have enough money to pay their dues, they are declared insolvent, you must write off this asset, call it bad debt. Non performing asset
If, later on the customer gives the money, you account it as an income
Following the principle of conservatism, companies are required to keep a provision for "doubtful" debts


Wages is what is paid to the blue collar staff and salary is what is paid to the white collar staff
Losses are something against which the business receives no benefit
Profit -> Income-Expenses

Say soma starts a tea stall, he brings in 1000 rupees and borrows 1000 rupees. It is borrowed on the condition that at the end of every month he will have to pay 300 rupees. That's all he can borrow at the present Soma starts with 2000 rupees. Total capital employed is 1000 rupees (owner's funds/ shareholders funds) and 1000 rupees of borrowed money (debt/borrowings) Hot plate, vessels, crockery, etc is bought by soma for 1000 rupees. These are fixed assets. Then He buys his raw material like tea, milk, etc. These are his stock/inventory of working capital for 500 rupees. 500 rupees is left On day 1 he sells 100 cups of tea at 5 rupees each. The tradition in the area is that you're paid the next day. Soma hasn't received a single rupee yet but he knows he will receive tomorrow(accounts receivable) He is left with 200 rupees worth of stock which is usable on the next day He has hired a helper wjo will cost him 50 rupees a day. The helpers salary will be paid on a weekly basis. Besides,he has to pay 10 rupees as interest on the loan Soma has not recieved a single penny at the end of day 1, but we know that he generated sales of 500 rupees and material cost was only 300 rupees. In other words,his gross profit was 200 rupees. Sales-direct revenue expenditure = gross profit We are taking into account sales and expenses only without any cash coming in, this is called the accrual principle Consider material cost on day 1. Logically,we take material cost at 300 rupees If soma has to close his business the next day, his fixed assets will barely sell for 200 rupees, so do we take this as a loss of 800 rupees? no cus going converna and all so we gotta keep positive If at the end of the day someone promises you that he will buy 200 cups at 6 rupees, you cant mark that as a profit cus conservatism Copy


Fixed assets- form the productive capacity for any business and are not traded in the course of the business
Current assets - the ones that will get converted into cash within a regular operator cycle
Current liabilities - are liabilities expected to e paid in cash in normal business cycle


Refer to ppt - vishy says its the set of all accounts


Nominal accounts - all accounts related to income or expenses
Real accounts - Anything that can be owned - only fixed assets,stocks and cash- Whatever you can hear see, touch
Personal accounts - personal account, related to an entity, like bank account, customer account, vendor account, loan taken from a bank. They are personal accounts since they represent an entity, they can be assets or liabilities
Jaise sales is nomial account, customer is personal account,
Golden matrix (refer to ppt)
Cash and stock are real and bank and debtors are personal
Liabilities are all personal since they are all related directly to an entity

Quote "Whatever notions you have about debit and credit, please maro CTR+ALT+DELETE"

For personal account, debit the receiver, credit the giver
For real account, debit what comes in, credit what goes out
For nominal account, debit all expenses and losses, credit all incomes and gains Example cash sales - sales and cash accounts. Sales is nominal, cash is real. Sales mein credit, cash mein debit
debit and credit are only accounting operators


STep 1 - identify the accounts affected
STep 2 - for each account, identify the type (real, nominal, personal)
STep 3 - ask the appropriate question based on the type (questions given above) to register it as credit or debit Done Up till here in the presentation
Gross is the value, and net is the gross minus deductions
Gross is usually the higher value and net is the lower value
Eg. net profit = gross profit - taxes, expenses, depreciation
How is the cash discount accounted for?
Accounts quiz 1
A personal account is impacted only when it is an unsettled transaction or it is a settlement of a previously unsettled transaction. The exception to this rule is the bank account, whenever you receive a cheque, it goes straight ot the bank account
Tip Advance is an unsettled transaction, it's like a loan to someone
sundry means miscellaneous


The process of accounting:
Identifying the event
converting the event into monetary terms
recording the journal entry
posting to ledger account - its a place where all the accounts are kept, so that you know whether you're insolvent or not
Preparing the trial balance - this is a quick check of whether your accounts are correct and you can check this using the credit and debit totalling 0. If they don't, you need to fix a few things and adjust some transactions
Preparing the final acounts: Profit and loss account and balance sheet


Usually in a business, transactions that are debited and credited are recorded in a systematic manner and the book in which they are recorded, in a chronological order is called the journal.
The fields that exist in a journal- date, particulars, LF, debit, credit
particulars is the account to be credited or debited and if it's to be debited, it's suffixed by Dr and if it's to be credited, its prefixed by to
After a particular entry is written, a narration must be written for an audit trail
LF- ledger folio, folio means page number.Once an entry is passed, it's posted in a ledger and the page it's posted on is called the LF

The book which contains accounts is called the ledger

Important Provision for doubtful debts is from the amount of doubtful debts that didnt become bad debts and they collected on it

item.title: Critical Thinking
item.description:
Not my advice, just stuff my sister, professors and books say
I'd like to keep philosophy out of these notes, but this seems really interesting and important.
This section will be about how to assimilate knowledge and really understand it critically and understand all the little kinks about it



These are "at the heart of critical thinking", to unde
Questions for clarification: clarifying the thinking behind a certain concept - "Why do you say that?", "Could you explain further?", "How does the concentration suddenly reduce on entry of a stream to a CSTR", "Whats the blow off cock there for in a boiler?", "How does the triple product of these partial derivatives equal -1?", "Whats the physical significance of exergy, gibbs free energy, enthalpy,etc"
Questions that probe assumptions - "Why is there no temperature gradient from the boundary layer to the center of the fluid in the pipe?", "Why does entropy always increase?"("just cus")
Questions that probe reasons and evidence - "Could the cold vodka be cause for the antidote not neutralizing the poison?"
Questions about viewpoints and perspectives - "Why don't we use exergy balance here instead of gibbs energy balance?", "Why did maxwell come up with his relations in thermodynamics? What was going on in his mind? Why did he feel the need for it?", "When should I use -this concept- over -that concept-"
Questions about implications and consequences: "If I did exergy balance for this instead of energy balance, what would be different? Isn't it still correct?"
Questions about the question: "What was the point of this question?", "Was that question easy?", "Would we use the concept of entropy in this question?", "How does this question relate to the lecture taken today?"


Basically analyzing, applying standards, discriminating, information seeking, logical reasoning, predicting and transforming knowledge over different situations
These actions aren't too helpful to a student since it's difficult to use this list to develop a critical understanding of a subject. This is probably for teachers to assess students and all


For the theory, ask socratic questions (good ones)
For the questions - ask another question or different calculations for the problem, think of all the ways you could solve the problem incorrectly (and why they're incorrect), think of how to make the problem easier, more difficult or more exciting, make a list of concepts taught in the problem and what the point of the problem was, vary parameters of the questions and study their consequences, try to come up with better ways of solving the problem (more elegant ways - my own addition)
